ranked_diseases.explanation: Classic presentation with obesity, intellectual disability, and retinal dystrophy causing myopia, reduced visual acuity, and nyctalopia. BBS1 is the most common form.
Presents with obesity, progressive vision loss, and nyctalopia due to cone-rod dystrophy. Intellectual disability is less common but can occur.
Features intellectual disability, obesity (typically truncal), myopia, and progressive retinal dystrophy with night blindness.
Similar phenotype to BBS1 with obesity, intellectual disability, and retinal dystrophy. BBS2 mutations are less common.
Mental retardation, truncal obesity, retinal dystrophy, and micropenis syndrome. Fits most features but is extremely rare.
Another BBS subtype with similar clinical features including obesity, intellectual disability, and retinal degeneration.
Features obesity and intellectual disability, but visual problems are not typical. Included due to partial phenotypic overlap.
